lg.l: ‘Tis a pleasant time in the country when the song birds sweetly sing
From the topmost bough of every tree in the days of early Spring,
When the wild flowers bloom in the quiet lanes and the lamb and foal are seen
To bask and play in the sunshine, in the meadows broad and green.
‘Tis a pleasant time when the Autumn comes and with gentle showers of rain,
Makes moist the land to enable man to carefully sow the grain;
And e’en in Winter’s cold there’s joy, when a plenteous year has fled,
And placed enough in the barn to once more supply him with daily bread.

But ‘tis sad when a drought Drought. The Federation Drought, which commenced in 1895 and peaked in 1901-2, affected most of eastern Australia and is regarded as one of the continent’s worst droughts. comes on the land, when every pond is dry,

When the farmer’s stock tread ridges bare, till one by one they die, One by one they die. A correspondent for the Molong Argus wrote on 7 February 1896 that the season has been a disastrous one for both man and beast (p. 5).
When the sultry winds of summer blow for months o’er the parched land,
And slowly dying maize crops are to be seen on either hand.
No towering haystacks in the field are piled as in days of yore,
And the crops of wheat are lighter than ever was known before.
And no waving blades of grass can be seen as far as the naked eye
Can reach o’er the one time verdant lea toward the distant lower sky.
The orchard trees in the drought do not any fine ripe fruits supply,
For when green they fall to earth beneath where they brown and withered lie,
And many trees are dying now as they sway to and fro in the wind
A strange contrast to the seasons fair of years left far behind.
In vain the honest farmer looks for a cloudy sky at morn,
To see the rain beat round his home to revive the withering corn.
To overflow the dams, now dry, that the grass green and tall may grow,
So that the farm may appear as it did in summers long ago.
Thus the farmer’s toil has gone for nought, and though few slave as hard as he,
‘Tis a well known truth he may only get one harvest good in three,
For he cannot tell when the land is tilled, though he carefully sows the grain,
When harvest time when it next comes will bring him loss or gain.
